page.title: 01Ecology-Caerlaverlock W.Fowl
page.content: A square of sea, merse and rough grazing for sheep and cattel. The Solway shore in winter is the haunt of wild fowl, in particular the rare Spitzbergen Barnacle Goose. To provide safe grazing for the wintering flocks of barnacle geese. Sir Peter Scott in the image of Slimbridge was instrumental in creating the Caerlarcrock Wild Fowl Trust. It provides a refuge for over 10,000 barnacle geese: pink foot and greylag geese as well as thousands of other ducks, bewick and whopper swans and wading birds. There is an observation tower and visitors are taken on guided tours to hides overlooking the merse and areas where the geese feed. Caerlaverlock is the most northern UK breeding ground for Natterjack toads-butocalamita-which thrive on the merse/arable grass.
